articles.headline: Hazardous Conditions for the Auto Industry
articles.snippet: Industry sales have dropped 26.6 percent over all compared with a year ago, and automakers sold fewer than a million new cars in September, the first time since 1993.
articles.abstract: Industry sales have dropped 26.6 percent over all compared with a year ago, and automakers sold fewer than a million new cars in September, the first time since 1993.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For the first time since 1993, automakers sold fewer than a million new cars and trucks in a single month in the United States, as a reeling economy scared people away from showrooms in September, and many eager buyers were unable to get loans.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: For Purists, a Cut Above in Movies
articles.snippet: Vudu, a set-top box that offers instant playback of thousands of movies and TV shows, has not found huge success, despite the breadth of its offerings and the quality of its images.
articles.abstract: Vudu, a set-top box that offers instant playback of thousands of movies and TV shows, has not found huge success, despite the breadth of its offerings and the quality of its images.
articles.lead_paragraph: So Mrs. Hollywood comes home one day to find her husband bound and gagged, with a hole shot through his foot. “Honey!” she screams, racing to help him. “Who did this to you?”

articles.headline: Surveillance of Skype Messages Found in China
articles.snippet: A Canadian human rights group has uncovered a system that tracks politically charged text messages sent by customers of Tom-Skype, a joint venture of which eBay’s Skype is a partner.
articles.abstract: A Canadian human rights group has uncovered a system that tracks politically charged text messages sent by customers of Tom-Skype, a joint venture of which eBay’s Skype is a partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A group of Canadian human-rights activists and computer security researchers has discovered a huge surveillance system in China that monitors and archives certain Internet text conversations that include politically charged words.

articles.headline: Crisis Puts Tax Moves Into Play
articles.snippet: Several tax breaks and provisions aimed at families and businesses, but also rural schools, have been tacked onto the financial bailout legislation.
articles.abstract: Several tax breaks and provisions aimed at families and businesses, but also rural schools, have been tacked onto the financial bailout legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A long-stalled tax bill offering incentives for the use of renewable energy and providing tax breaks to millions of families and businesses gained momentum on Wednesday, when it was strapped onto emergency legislation to shore up the nation’s financial system.

articles.headline: Buffett’s Bet on G.E.: Almost as Good as a Bailout
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffet has announced he would invest $3 billion in General Electric, eight days after he said he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffet has announced he would invest $3 billion in General Electric, eight days after he said he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett is emerging as the banker of choice to the embattled blue-chip companies of American business.

articles.headline: Small Businesses Feeling the Chill
articles.snippet: Whether because banks won’t lend to them, or because they don’t want to take risks in a difficult market, small businesses have been sitting still.
articles.abstract: Whether because banks won’t lend to them, or because they don’t want to take risks in a difficult market, small businesses have been sitting still.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some small companies say they are no longer able to get loans from newly cautious banks as credit tightens across the country, and even those who do qualify are increasingly reluctant to borrow and expand, fearful of overextending themselves in the midst of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Life in Zimbabwe: Wait for Useless Money
articles.snippet: With Zimbabwe mired in hyperinflation, its people have been plunged into a Darwinian struggle to get by.
articles.abstract: With Zimbabwe mired in hyperinflation, its people have been plunged into a Darwinian struggle to get by.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Long before the rooster in their dirt yard crowed, Rose Moyo and her husband rolled out of bed. “It is time to get up,” intoned the robotic voice of her cellphone. Its glowing face displayed the time: 2:20 a.m.

articles.headline: Deposit Plan Will Cost Banks More
articles.snippet: The plan to raise the amount of deposit insurance on consumer accounts from $100,000 to $250,000 may leave the F.D.I.C., and taxpayers, in a bind.
articles.abstract: The plan to raise the amount of deposit insurance on consumer accounts from $100,000 to $250,000 may leave the F.D.I.C., and taxpayers, in a bind.
articles.lead_paragraph: When banks were flush, most of them paid nothing for a golden government guarantee. Bank failures were so rare that, for a decade, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation waived most of the premiums it normally would have collected to insure bank deposits.

articles.headline: As Credit Crisis Spiraled, Alarm Led to Action
articles.snippet: During a 36-hour period two weeks ago, the fissures opening in the worldwide financial system convinced policy makers that they needed to act quickly.
articles.abstract: During a 36-hour period two weeks ago, the fissures opening in the worldwide financial system convinced policy makers that they needed to act quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Andrew Ross Sorkin, Diana B. Henriques, Edmund L. Andrews and Joe Nocera. It was written by Mr. Nocera.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Diana B. Henriques, Edmund L. Andrews and Joe Nocera

articles.headline: An Everyman on the Trail, With Perks at Home
articles.snippet: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has benefited from resources and relationships not available to average Americans.
articles.abstract: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has benefited from resources and relationships not available to average Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the millions of voters getting to know him, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, portrays himself at times as an average guy who takes the train to work, frets about money and basically has led a middle-class life.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Persistent Anxiety Over Tight Credit Sends Stocks Plunging
articles.snippet: Declines in the stock market suggest that the problems of the tight credit market, once mostly contained to Wall Street, are spreading across the broader economy.
articles.abstract: Declines in the stock market suggest that the problems of the tight credit market, once mostly contained to Wall Street, are spreading across the broader economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped sharply on Thursday as signs of the economy’s worsening health and a continued choking of credit unnerved investors ahead of a crucial vote in Washington on a financial rescue plan.
